_**Queen Sugar**_ is an American drama television series created and executive
produced by [Ava DuVernay](/wiki/Ava_DuVernay "Ava DuVernay"), with [Oprah
Winfrey](/wiki/Oprah_Winfrey "Oprah Winfrey") serving as an executive
producer. DuVernay also directs many episodes. The series is based on the
[novel of the same name](/wiki/Queen_Sugar_\(novel\) "Queen Sugar \(novel\)")
by [Natalie Baszile](/wiki/Natalie_Baszile "Natalie Baszile").[1] The series
airs on [Oprah Winfrey Network](/wiki/Oprah_Winfrey_Network "Oprah Winfrey
Network") (OWN) and premiered on September 6, 2016.[1][2][3]

The series follows the life of three siblings: two sisters, Nova Bordelon
(played by [Rutina Wesley](/wiki/Rutina_Wesley "Rutina Wesley")), a formidable
journalist and activist from New Orleans, and Charley Bordelon ([Dawn-Lyen
Gardner](/wiki/Dawn-Lyen_Gardner "Dawn-Lyen Gardner")), a working wife and
mother, who, with her teenaged son Micah, leaves her upscale home in Los
Angeles and moves to the heart of [Louisiana](/wiki/Louisiana "Louisiana") to
claim an inheritance from her recently departed father – an 800-acre sugarcane
farm; and their brother, Ralph Angel Bordelon ([Kofi
Siriboe](/wiki/Kofi_Siriboe "Kofi Siriboe")), a single parent struggling with
unemployment and raising his son alone after his father's death.

_Queen Sugar_ has been speculated to be the first television show to feature
female directors for every episode of the series.[4] Critics have highlighted
that the show's predominantly Black cast does not preclude storylines that
tackle universal issues like culture, class, and gender.[5] The mainstream
themes in the series often go hand in hand with episodes on racial profiling,
the inheritance of [chattel slavery](/wiki/Chattel_slavery "Chattel slavery"),
and other issues related to African Americans. [6]

In August 2018, OWN renewed the series for a fourth season.[7]

## Cast and
characters[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Queen_Sugar&action=edit&section=1 "Edit
section: Cast and characters")]

### Main[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Queen_Sugar&action=edit&section=2 "Edit
section: Main")]

  * [Rutina Wesley](/wiki/Rutina_Wesley "Rutina Wesley") as Nova Bordelon, the eldest Bordelon child, a [journalist](/wiki/Journalist "Journalist"), [activist](/wiki/Activist "Activist") and [herbal healer](/wiki/Louisiana_Voodoo "Louisiana Voodoo")
  * [Dawn-Lyen Gardner](/wiki/Dawn-Lyen_Gardner "Dawn-Lyen Gardner") as Charlotte "Charley" Bordelon West, the middle Bordelon child - half sibling to Nova and Ralph Angel, a [sports manager](/wiki/Sports_manager "Sports manager"), mother of Micah and ex-wife of Davis
  * [Kofi Siriboe](/wiki/Kofi_Siriboe "Kofi Siriboe") as Ralph Angel Bordelon, the youngest Bordelon child, the face-forward brother of Bordelon sisters looking to better himself after recently being released from prison
  * [Tina Lifford](/wiki/Tina_Lifford "Tina Lifford") as Violet Bordelon, Ernest's younger sister, aunt to the Bordelon children, and Hollywood's girlfriend
  * [Omar Dorsey](/wiki/Omar_Dorsey "Omar Dorsey") as Hollingsworth "Hollywood" Desonier, Violet's much younger [oil rig worker](/wiki/Oil_platform "Oil platform") boyfriend and friend of the Bordelon family
  * [Dondre Whitfield](/wiki/Dondre_Whitfield "Dondre Whitfield") as Remy Newell, an irrigation specialist who was a friend and confidante to Ernest who soon becomes a helping hand to Ernest's children and soon becomes Charley's love interest
  * [Bianca Lawson](/wiki/Bianca_Lawson "Bianca Lawson") as Darla, Ralph Angel's ex-girlfriend and Blue's mother, seeking to reconnect with them both as she is in recovery from a drug addiction
  * Nicholas L. Ashe as Micah West, Charley's and Davis's teenage son
  * Ethan Hutchison as Blue Bordelon, Ralph Angel and Darla's 6-year-old son
  * [Henry G. Sanders](/wiki/Henry_G._Sanders "Henry G. Sanders") as Prosper Denton, a lifelong friend to Ernest and fellow farmer (Season 3; Recurring Seasons 1-2)
  * Timon Kyle Durrett as Davis West, Charley's charismatic star [basketball player](/wiki/Basketball_player "Basketball player") ex-husband, client, and Micah's father whose involvement in a sex scandal leads to the dissolution of their marriage (Seasons 1-3)
  * [Greg Vaughan](/wiki/Greg_Vaughan "Greg Vaughan") as Calvin, a married [police officer](/wiki/Police_officer "Police officer") and Nova's longtime secret lover (Season 1; Guest Season 2)
  * Marycarmen Lopez as Reyna Velez, Blue's elementary school [teacher](/wiki/Teacher "Teacher") (Season 1)

### Recurring[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Queen_Sugar&action=edit&section=3
"Edit section: Recurring")]

  * [Glynn Turman](/wiki/Glynn_Turman "Glynn Turman") as Ernest Bordelon, the patriarch of the Bordelon family and older brother of Violet (season 1)
  * [True O'Brien](/wiki/True_O%27Brien "True O'Brien") as Stella, Micah's girlfriend before he leaves Los Angeles (season 1)[8]
  * [Reagan Gomez-Preston](/wiki/Reagan_Gomez-Preston "Reagan Gomez-Preston") as Chantal Williams, Nova's friend
  * Issac White as Devonte "Too Sweet" Bonclair, a teen who after being falsely imprisoned becomes the main focus of Nova's current crusade on how the [parish](/wiki/Parish_\(administrative_division\) "Parish \(administrative division\)") DA has been railroading African-Americans (season 1; guest, season 3)
  * Tanyell Waivers as Keke Raymond, a teenage friend of the family who Micah sets his sights on after meeting her at a family [cook-out](/wiki/Cook-out "Cook-out")[9]
  * Deja Dee as Sierra, Nova's college roommate
  * [Sharon Lawrence](/wiki/Sharon_Lawrence "Sharon Lawrence") as Lorna Prescott, Charley's mother
  * [Michael Michele](/wiki/Michael_Michele "Michael Michele") as Darlene, Darla's mother
  * [Roger Guenveur Smith](/wiki/Roger_Guenveur_Smith "Roger Guenveur Smith") as Quincy, Darla's father
  * [Alimi Ballard](/wiki/Alimi_Ballard "Alimi Ballard") as Dr. Robert Dubois, an activist, who becomes Nova's love interest briefly in the second season
  * Lea Coco as Jacob Boudreaux, a member of the Landry family who takes a special interest in Charley
  * [David Jensen](/wiki/David_Jensen "David Jensen") as Samuel Landry, the owner of the most popular mill, the Landry mills, in the county who Charley and Ralph-Angel go up against
  * Walter Perez as Romero, a doctor and love interest to Charley (season 3)
  * Vivien Ngô as Trinh Phan, a young woman who returns to help her parents with their seafood plant who becomes Ralph Angel's love interest. (season 3) [10][11]
  * Tony Aidan Vo as Khanh Phan, the younger brother to Trinh and son of Mrs. Phan (season 3) [10]
  * Elyse Dinh McCrillis as Mrs. Phan, a Vietnamese American refugee and the mother to Khanh and Trinh; also Ralph Angel's boss at the seafood plant (season 3) [10]

## Production[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Queen_Sugar&action=edit&section=4
"Edit section: Production")]

### Development[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Queen_Sugar&action=edit&section=5
"Edit section: Development")]

On February 2, 2015, it was announced that [Oprah Winfrey
Network](/wiki/Oprah_Winfrey_Network "Oprah Winfrey Network") had ordered a
straight-to-series TV drama based on _Queen Sugar_ , the novel by Natalie
Baszile.[1][2][12][13] [Ava DuVernay](/wiki/Ava_DuVernay "Ava DuVernay") and
[Oprah Winfrey](/wiki/Oprah_Winfrey "Oprah Winfrey"), who worked on the 2014
film _[Selma](/wiki/Selma_\(film\) "Selma \(film\)")_ , co-created the series,
while DuVernay was set to write and direct the initial episodes. The first
season began filming in February 2016[14] and contained 13 episodes. DuVernay
announced on January 27, 2016 that the series would feature an all-women
directorial team.[15] On February 15, 2016, [Neema
Barnette](/wiki/Neema_Barnette "Neema Barnette") joined the series as director
and producer.[16] Award-winning director [Tina Mabry](/wiki/Tina_Mabry "Tina
Mabry") is a producer and will also direct two episodes, and [Anthony
Sparks](/wiki/Anthony_Sparks "Anthony Sparks"),[17] an award-winning TV writer
and professor, is a co-executive producer for the series.[18] It was later
announced that singer-songwriter [Meshell
Ndegeocello](/wiki/Meshell_Ndegeocello "Meshell Ndegeocello") would provide
the score for the series.[19]

### Casting[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Queen_Sugar&action=edit&section=6 "Edit
section: Casting")]

On January 13, 2016, it was announced that [Rutina Wesley](/wiki/Rutina_Wesley
"Rutina Wesley") would play the role of Nova Bordelon.[20][21][22] Further
casting was announced January 27, 2016. [Dawn-Lyen Gardner](/wiki/Dawn-
Lyen_Gardner "Dawn-Lyen Gardner"), [Kofi Siriboe](/wiki/Kofi_Siriboe "Kofi
Siriboe"), and [Omar Dorsey](/wiki/Omar_Dorsey "Omar Dorsey"), who co-starred
in _Selma_ , were all announced in leading roles.[23][24] On February 1, 2016,
it was announced that [Emmy Award](/wiki/Emmy_Award "Emmy Award")-winner
[Glynn Turman](/wiki/Glynn_Turman "Glynn Turman") will guest-star as Ernest
Bordelon, the patriarch of the family who died in the first episode.[25] On
February 16, 2016, it was announced that [Tina Lifford](/wiki/Tina_Lifford
"Tina Lifford"), [Dondre Whitfield](/wiki/Dondre_Whitfield "Dondre
Whitfield"), Timon Kyle Durrett and Nicholas L. Ashe were cast as series
regulars.[26] On February 23, 2016, [Bianca Lawson](/wiki/Bianca_Lawson
"Bianca Lawson") and [Greg Vaughan](/wiki/Greg_Vaughan "Greg Vaughan") joined
the cast as regulars, while [Henry G. Sanders](/wiki/Henry_G._Sanders "Henry
G. Sanders") joined in a recurring role. Meanwhile, Oprah Winfrey Network said
that Oprah Winfrey, who earlier was announced as a recurring character, would
not have an onscreen role.[27] On March 11, 2016, it was announced that
Marycarmen Lopez also was cast as regular.[28]

### Seasons[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Queen_Sugar&action=edit&section=7 "Edit
section: Seasons")]

On August 1, 2016, the series was renewed for a second season ahead of its
television premiere which aired in a two-night premiere on June 20 and June
21, 2017.[29][30] The second season premiered on OWN in a two episode special
on June 20 and 21, 2017. The show was renewed for a third season on July 26,
2017.[31] The third season premiered in a two-night special on May 29 and May
30, 2018. On August 8, 2018, the series was renewed for a fourth season.
Following the renewal co-executive producer Anthony Sparks was revealed to be
the new showrunner, replacing the current showrunner Kat Candler.[7]

## Reception[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Queen_Sugar&action=edit&section=13
"Edit section: Reception")]

### Critical
response[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Queen_Sugar&action=edit&section=14 "Edit
section: Critical response")]

The [review aggregator](/wiki/Review_aggregator "Review aggregator") website
[Rotten Tomatoes](/wiki/Rotten_Tomatoes "Rotten Tomatoes") reported a 93%
approval rating for the first season, with an average rating of 7.4/10 based
on 41 reviews. The website's critical consensus reads, "With an authenticity
of culture and place and strong performances throughout, Queen Sugar rises
above melodrama in this alluring, unhurried and powerful portrait of a
fractious black American family."[75] [Metacritic](/wiki/Metacritic
"Metacritic"), which uses a weighted average, assigned a score of 75 out of
100 based on 25 critics for the season, indicating what the website considers
to be "generally favorable reviews".[76] A 100% approval rating for the second
season was reported by Rotten Tomatoes, with an average rating of 8.03/10
based on 7 reviews.[77]

## Novel[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Queen_Sugar&action=edit&section=15 "Edit
section: Novel")]

Main article: [Queen Sugar (novel)](/wiki/Queen_Sugar_\(novel\) "Queen Sugar
\(novel\)")

[UCLA](/wiki/UCLA "UCLA") graduate Natalie Baszile started writing _Queen
Sugar_ , the novel, in the early 1990s, but the text was only completed ten
years later. She first presented the manuscript to publishers in 2009 but
without any success. After revising the book for another two years, she
resubmitted the text, with one agent agreeing to represent her.

Baszile took part in a women writer's retreat in [Hedgebrook](/wiki/Hedgebrook
"Hedgebrook"). A friend of hers who was also at the retreat, the novelist
Sarah Manyika, suggested that she read part of _Queen Sugar_ to fellow
residents. Leigh Haber, _[O, The Oprah Magazine](/wiki/O,_The_Oprah_Magazine
"O, The Oprah Magazine")'_s book editor was attending and loved the novel and
passed it to people at Oprah's [Harpo Productions](/wiki/Harpo_Productions
"Harpo Productions"). A few months after that, Harpo called to say they wanted
to option the book for a project.[78]

The book was published by Penguin in 2014 as Baszile's debut novel and, a few
months later, OWN negotiated the deal to turn the book into a television
series.
